Brief Description: A predominately pink and purple work on paper framed behind non-glare glass.

This painting occupies one entire wall of the Staff Lifts in Rankine Brown.  Oil on board, in various shades of brown, it depicts a desert/hill/mountain range.  On top of some of the "hills" are numbers - for example, in the top right hand corner there is a hill with 1865 on it, another in the middle top third with 586 on it, and at the bottom centre of the painting another hill appears with the numbers 66115.  There are also hills with individual numbers sitting on them, but the numbers used are always 1,5,6, or 8.  In the top left third of the painting there is a small painted banner with the words "Nga Ingoa" and another beneath with "Hou".  In the bottom right hand corner it has been signed "Katene Cotton 1994".  The work has a perspex cover and a handrail screwed into it on the bottom half of the painting.
Collection: Victoria University of Wellington Art Collection
Credit Line: Victoria University of Wellington Art Collection, commissioned 1993

Brief Description: Single Channel video and sound work from the 'Polar Projects' series filmed in Antarctica in 2003. Echo-Logo is a sound-echo performance staged under the 30 metre high ice-face of the Canada Glacier, located in the dry valley environment of the Taylor Valley, Antarctica. The event was realised at 1 am, with the assistance of an 8 member science team, based in the valley during summer.  The event consists of simple performer tasks - walking cycles, voice shouts and stone bangs, producing dynamic echo-effects off the glacial ice-wall. Echo-Logo performed by Bu Windsor, Ian Whiteley, and the K024 Science team; Allan Green, Liam Nolan, Roman Turk, Leo Sancho, Burkhard Beudel, Hans Reichenberg. Canada Glacier face, Taylor Valley, Antarctica, 00.30, 24.1.2003.

Brief Description: Halberd Head....was produced during a residency in New York City in 2008. It shows an attempt by the artist to capture onto film an Indonesian artefact on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. As still photography was only accepted by the museum, Spong created a simple pinhole camera using a cartridge of super 8 film to produce the work. The filmic outcome is an abstraction of light and its effects. It has no sound. Instead it gives form to the materiality of the film medium and captures the process of the artist producing the work evident by the recorded rhythm of the artist winding on the film. Further colour filters have been applied to intensify the intermittent flickering of the light effects.

Brief Description: From the 'arbitrary knowledges' series. Chalky pale blue ground with delicately rendered surfaces details, including patches of overlapping white, green, yellow and pink with light pencil scrawlspainted onto hardboard. It is typical of the artists improvisational abstraction which explores the limits of language and seeks to create a space for thought between differing sign systems. In this her titles are highly significant. Not only do they appear hand written on the surface of the work, but they generate a layer of meaning in conversation with the surface details that allows the viewers mind to wander in certain directions. The text of this work is drawn from the lyrics of a Talking Heads song written by David Byrne and Brian Eno, Once in a Lifetime.

This work replaces Dawsons earlier work Flying Steps (2000) which engaged with the idea of aspirational steps taken to higher levels in education. The stylised two dimensional mortarboard in Toss represents the headgear worn by students at graduation and references the light-hearted celebratory tradition of newly graduated students throwing the mortarboard into the air.

Brief Description: A selection of fourteen still images and CD soundtrack from the interactive installation 'Citywalk' (1989) originally commissioned by and shown at City Gallery Wellington. The images are taken using Kodak vericolor slide film giving the images a characteristic blue colouring with highlights of magenta and yellow. This film is intended to be used for producing same-size positive transparencies from colour negatives or for making reduced-size transparencies from larger negatives. It has a slow reaction to movement and the outdoor environment causing the images to capture a staggered blurry movement of elements within the picture frame.  In the original installation, moving still images were projected onto the gallery walls. Wireless headphones were supplied to the views with a soundtrack broadcasted via FM radio. This soundtrack was made up of fragments of city noise, conversations, cars, snippets of music and the buzzing of lights.The movement of the images is activated by the movement of the viewers through the space creating an individually experienced soundscape and visual experience. This work places emphasis on the individual experience of the exterior cityscape thereby drawing attention to an interior private and hidden cityscape or the internal mindspace of the city.

Brief Description: A selection of six out of twenty-four from Shaun Waughs Covenant Cut-outs series of framed landscapes. Several of these document land that has been identified by its owners as having natural or cultural value worthy of protection, over which a covenant has been placed by entering into legal agreement with the Queen Elizabeth II National Trust to safeguard the site in perpetuity. All of these sites feature a section of the view that is presented as a solid block of colour. The viewer is left to determine whether these are the protected zones, or whether they have been singled out by the artist for some other reason. The 24 works are arranged according to these coloured sections, which conform to their place on the grid of a photographic colour picker chart available via the software used by the artist. This selection represents the second row of the chart.
